title: Time-to-Action Analysis
insights:
Analysis of Bus Ticket Booking App Latency

The analysis of user flow latency and time-to-action metrics for the bus ticket booking app has been completed. Below are the detailed findings based on the computed latencies between key events.

SLOWEST TRANSITION

The pair with the highest median latency is from select_seat to payment_initiate with a median latency of 131.8 seconds. This is significantly outside the benchmark of 60-180 seconds for seat selection and passenger details.

BOTTLENECK ANALYSIS

There are notable bottlenecks in the user flow:

  • The transition from bus_result to select_seat has a median latency of 50.8 seconds and a P90 of 140.0 seconds. This indicates a potential UX issue as the median is already close to the upper limit of the benchmark.
  • The transition from select_seat to payment_initiate shows a high mean latency of 384.3 seconds and a P90 of 594.1 seconds, suggesting a significant technical bottleneck.

END-TO-END TIME

The full search-to-payment flow takes a median of 527.0 seconds (approximately 8.8 minutes), which is above the competitive benchmark of 3-8 minutes for a healthy flow. This indicates that the overall user experience may be suffering due to excessive latency.

SPEED IMPROVEMENTS

To reduce latency, the following specific strategies can be implemented:

  • Optimize Seat Selection Process: Streamline the UI and reduce the number of steps required to select a seat. Expected time savings: 30-60 seconds.
  • Improve Backend Response Times: Enhance server performance to reduce the time taken to fetch results and process selections. Expected time savings: 20-40 seconds.
  • Implement Caching Mechanisms: Use caching for frequently accessed data to speed up the transition from results to seat selection. Expected time savings: 15-30 seconds.

These improvements can help in aligning the app's performance with industry benchmarks and enhance user satisfaction.
